paper_metadata.title: Induced Pluripotent Stem Cell Modeling of Multisystemic, Hereditary Transthyretin Amyloidosis
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the TTR gene variant L55P, including penetrance data and individual records.

patients.demographics: Heterozygous patient, specific demographics not provided
patients.phenotype: ATTR disease, clinically aggressive variant targeting heart and peripheral nervous system

individual_records.phenotype_details: Clinically aggressive variant of ATTR disease
individual_records.evidence_sentence: This mutation, one of the most clinically aggressive variants of ATTR disease (Jacobson et al., 1992), produces a highly unstable and amyloidogenic TTR, clinically targeting the heart and the peripheral nervous system.

functional_data.summary: The L55P variant produces unstable and amyloidogenic TTR, leading to cellular damage in target organs.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in the patient.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical and functional studies.
variants.additional_notes: The L55P variant is associated with significant morbidity and early mortality in affected families.
key_quotes: Survival after ATTR disease onset is usually only 5–15 years.
The majority of patients with ATTR are heterozygous for one autosomal-dominant mutation in the TTR gene.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text, focusing on the TTR gene.
